condition.description:
Pain is a feeling triggered in the nervous system. Pain may be sharp or dull. It may come and go, or it may be constant. You may feel pain in one area of your body, such as your back, abdomen or chest or you may feel pain all over, such as when your muscles ache from the flu.

Pain can be helpful in diagnosing a problem. Without pain, you might seriously hurt yourself without knowing it, or you might not realize you have a medical problem that needs treatment. Once you take care of the problem, pain usually goes away. However, sometimes pain goes on for weeks, months or even years. This is called chronic pain. Sometimes chronic pain is due to an ongoing cause, such as cancer or arthritis. Sometimes the cause is unknown.

Fortunately, there are many ways to treat pain. Treatment varies depending on the cause of pain. Pain relievers, acupuncture and sometimes surgery are helpful.
condition.name: Pain

carousel_items: This is a combination pain medication. It contains both an opioid medicine, and acetaminophen (Tylenol).
Starts working in 30 minutes.
Works best if you take it as soon as you start feeling pain.
Pain relief lasts 4-6 hours.
Can make you dizzy or drowsy.
Avoid activities need you to be fully alert until you know how it affects you.
Take it with food to lower the chance of an upset stomach.
Constipation is common and may not go away while you're taking this medicine. Drinking lots of water and using laxatives can help.
Don't take more than instructed to prevent liver damage.
Use it for the shortest time possible, and at the lowest dose possible, to lower your chance of becoming addicted.
Talk to your doctor if it doesn't help enough for your pain, or if the side effects are really bad.

clock.tip: Take with food or milk to lower stomach upset.

basics.benefits_moa: Acetaminophen with codeine is a combination pain medicine. Codeine is an opioid (similar to morphine) that works in the brain to lower pain perception. Acetaminophen is a non-opioid pain reliever and fever reducer.
basics.bottom_line: Acetaminophen with codeine is a good option to treat pain and cough as needed when over-the-counter medicines can't control the symptoms, but must make sure you don't take too much acetaminophen (Tylenol) to avoid liver problems or death.
downsides: Dizziness and drowsiness is common, but your body may adjust.
Everyone will get constipation - always stay hydrated and take stool softener or stimulant on days you're taking Acetaminophen with codeine if you need.
All opioid containing medicines have the risk of physical dependence and possibility of withdrawal when used long-term.
The non-opioid part of Acetaminophen with codeine, acetaminophen (Tylenol), has a high risk of liver failure and death if you take more than the maximum daily dose. Be very careful.
Relies on the users to be aware of how much acetaminophen (Tylenol) they are using since it is a very common ingredient in many prescription and non-prescription pain medicines.
Avoid alcohol.

carousel_items: Contains ibuprofen, so take it with food to avoid stomach problems and ulcers.
Diphenhydramine makes you tired, so take Advil PM before you go to sleep.
Don't take Advil PM with alcohol or other drugs that make you sleepy.
Don't take Advil PM if you're pregnant.

basics.benefits_moa: Advil PM is a combination medicine that treats cold and flu symptoms. Ibuprofen is an NSAID that relieves pain and reduces fever. Diphenhydramine is an antihistamine that treats runny nose and watery eyes and helps you sleep.
basics.bottom_line: Advil PM works well at relieving pain and also helps you sleep.
downsides: The pain reliever (ibuprofen) can interact with other medications and make health problems like stomach bleeding and ulcers worse.
The antihistamine (diphenhydramine) can make you feel groggy the next morning.
Can only take one dose in 24 hours.
Can increase the risk of falls, so elderly people shouldn't use it.

downsides_processed.orig: The pain reliever (ibuprofen) can interact with other medications and make health problems like stomach bleeding and ulcers worse.

risks_warnings.title: Stomach bleeding
risks_warnings.description: Advil PM contains aspirin, which can cause serious problems including inflammation, bleeding, and ulcers in the stomach or intestines. The longer you take Advil PM, the higher the risk is. If you notice blood or a dark/black color in your stool, tell your doctor right away.
risk_factors: History of stomach bleeding or ulcers
Taking aspirin, NSAIDs, or blood thinners
Drinking more than 3 alcoholic beverages a day

risks_warnings.title: Harm to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Advil PM can harm unborn babies. Ibuprofen can increase the risk of a heart defect in an unborn baby if you take it during the last 3 months of pregnancy (last trimester). Talk with your doctor or pharmacist about what's safe and will work best for you while pregnant.

description_processed.orig: Advil PM can harm unborn babies. Ibuprofen can increase the risk of a heart defect in an unborn baby if you take it during the last 3 months of pregnancy (last trimester). Talk with your doctor or pharmacist about what's safe and will work best for you while pregnant.

risks_warnings.title: Heart attack or stroke
risks_warnings.description: Advil PM contains ibuprofen, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). It can lower the benefit of low-dose aspirin (81 mg/day) in people taking it to prevent heart attacks and stroke, especially if taking both drugs together for a long time. If you take aspirin every day, take Advil PM more than 8 hours before your aspirin dose and at least 30 minutes after your aspirin dose to lower this risk.

risks_warnings.title: Heart failure
risks_warnings.description: Advil PM contains ibuprofen, an NSAID. NSAIDs can increase the risk of fluid buildup and swelling in the limbs. This can worsen heart failure, so the American Heart Association recommends that older people with heart failure and reduced heart function avoid taking NSAIDs.

basics.bottom_line: Alka-Seltzer gives quick relief for headache, body pains, and upset tummies, but might be hard to swallow if you don't like the taste or fizz.
downsides: Doesn't last very long.
Other antacids like Zantac (H2 blockers) and omeprazole (proton pump inhibitors) can work better and last longer.

risks_warnings.title: Taking the wrong medication
risks_warnings.description: There are many different over the counter medications with the brand name Alka-Seltzer.  Each one may contain different active ingredients. Be sure to read the labels carefully to understand what kind of medicine you have and what the correct dose should be.

description_processed.orig: There are many different over the counter medications with the brand name Alka-Seltzer.  Each one may contain different active ingredients. Be sure to read the labels carefully to understand what kind of medicine you have and what the correct dose should be.

risks_warnings.title: High blood sodium levels
risks_warnings.description: If you have kidney or hyperparathyroid disease Alka-Seltzer can build up in your blood.  This may can cause toxic levels of sodium in your body. This is more likely if you have severe kidney disease (defined as a kidney function blood test called GFR of less than 30ml/min).  If you have severe kidney disease or are on kidney dialysis don't use Alka-Seltzer; a different antacid would be better for you.

risks_warnings.title: May worsen heart or kidney problems
risks_warnings.description: Alka-Seltzer contains sodium. Sodium can raise blood pressure and cause your body to hold on to water. If you have high blood pressure, heart failure, or kidney disease you should not take Alka-Seltzer.

risks_warnings.title: Brain damage or death from Reye's Syndrome
risks_warnings.description: Alka-Seltzer use is linked to a condition called Reye's syndrome that causes liver and brain swelling. This is rare but very serious. Let your doctor know about any nausea, vomiting, unusually low energy, or changes in behavior.
risk_factors: Children 18 years or younger recovering from viral infections

risks_warnings.title: Stomach Bleeding
risks_warnings.description: Alka-Seltzer can cause serious stomach problems that include swelling, ulcers, bleeding, and holes in the stomach or intestines. These problems can be life threatening and can cause death. The chances that a stomach problem will occur might be worse the longer you take this medication but it can happen at any time.  Watch out for blood or dark colored stools when you go to the bathroom.  This can be a medical emergency and you should get help right away.
risk_factors: History of stomach bleeding or ulcers
Drinking 3 or more alcoholic drinks a day

basics.benefits_moa: Aspirin is a salicylate and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). It blocks the inflammation process in your body, which relieves swelling and pain. It also prevents blood platelets from forming clots, which thins your blood.
basics.bottom_line: A low dose of Aspirin (81mg) every day can protect your heart, but it's not the best medicine to take for pain, swelling, or fever.
downsides: Not a preferred medication for treating pain, swelling, or fever due to its high risk of bleeding.
NSAIDs (like ibuprofen and naproxen) and acetaminophen (Tylenol) are better for treating pain and fever thank aspirin.
Aspirin raises your risk of bleeding, especially when used with other blood thinner medications like warfarin (Coumadin).
Studies show that using higher doses of Aspirin (162 mg or more) every day raises your risk of stomach bleeding and doesn't provide any additional heart protection.

basics.benefits_moa: Celebrex is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). It blocks the inflammation process in your body, which relieves swelling and pain.
basics.bottom_line: Celebrex works well for treating pain and causes less upset stomach than other NSAIDs.
downsides: It's not available as a generic medication, so it's more expensive than many alternatives.
The longer you take Celebrex, the more likely you are to have stomach problems, including inflammation, ulcers, and bleeding. This can also happen if you take Celebrex on an empty stomach.
Like all NSAIDs, it can raise your risk of blood clots, heart attack, or a stroke.
Can also affect your kidneys or cause permanent kidney damage if taken for a long time.

risks_warnings.description: Celebrex can raise your blood pressure, especially if you've had high blood pressure or you're taking water pills to treat your blood pressure. Check your blood pressure regularly as instructed by your doctor if this becomes a concern.

description_processed.orig: Celebrex can raise your blood pressure, especially if you've had high blood pressure or you're taking water pills to treat your blood pressure. Check your blood pressure regularly as instructed by your doctor if this becomes a concern.

risks_warnings.title: Increased swelling (edema) and fluid retention
risks_warnings.description: Celebrex can cause your arms and legs to swell, or can cause you to retain water, especially if you've been diagnosed with heart failure.

description_processed.orig: Celebrex can cause your arms and legs to swell, or can cause you to retain water, especially if you've been diagnosed with heart failure.

risks_warnings.title: Skin reactions
risks_warnings.description: Some people taking Celebrex have had serious skin reactions, possibly leading to death. However, this has been very rare. Call your doctor or seek emergency help immediately if you develop a sudden high fever with a rash.

description_processed.orig: Some people taking Celebrex have had serious skin reactions, possibly leading to death. However, this has been very rare. Call your doctor or seek emergency help immediately if you develop a sudden high fever with a rash.

risks_warnings.title: Asthma attacks
risks_warnings.description: Some people taking Celebrex have had serious asthma attacks. However, this has been very rare. Talk to your doctor if you've had a history of asthma.

description_processed.orig: Some people taking Celebrex have had serious asthma attacks. However, this has been very rare. Talk to your doctor if you've had a history of asthma.

risks_warnings.title: Lowered kidney function
risks_warnings.description: Celebrex, and similar medications in the NSAID family, can cause lower kidney function or cause permanent kidney damage.  You're at higher risk for this if you've a history of kidney disease, heart failure, and liver disease.  Taking Diuretic, ACE inhibitor, or Angiotensin Receptor Blocker (ARB) medications also increases your risk. If you are 65 or older you're also at a higher risk for these types of kidney problems.

description_processed.orig: Celebrex, and similar medications in the NSAID family, can cause lower kidney function or cause permanent kidney damage.  You're at higher risk for this if you've a history of kidney disease, heart failure, and liver disease.  Taking Diuretic, ACE inhibitor, or Angiotensin Receptor Blocker (ARB) medications also increases your risk. If you are 65 or older you're also at a higher risk for these types of kidney problems.

risks_warnings.title: Harm to unborn babies

downsides: Ibuprofen doesn't work as long as other NSAIDs, so follow the package directions on how often you can take it.

basics.benefits_moa: Tylenol PM is a combination medicine that treats cold and flu symptoms. Acetaminophen relieves pain and reduces fever. Diphenhydramine is an antihistamine that treats runny nose and watery eyes and helps you sleep.
basics.bottom_line: Tylenol PM works well at relieving pain and also helps you sleep.
downsides: The antihistamine (diphenhydramine) can make you feel groggy the next morning.
Can increase the risk of falls, so elderly people shouldn't use it.
To avoid hurting your liver, you have to keep track of the total amount of acetaminophen (APAP) you're taking since it's a very common ingredient in pain and cold/flu combination medicines.
Can only take one dose in 24 hours.

risks_warnings.title: Liver damage
risks_warnings.description: Tylenol PM contains acetaminophen, also known as Tylenol or APAP, and is a common ingredient in many other over-the-counter medicines. basics.benefits_moa: Diclofenac sodium is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). It blocks the inflammation process in your body, which relieves swelling and pain.
basics.bottom_line: Diclofenac sodium works well for pain and causes less upset stomach than other NSAIDs.
downsides: Can cause serious stomach problems like inflammation, ulcers, and bleeding. The chances that a stomach problem will occur is worse the longer you take this medication, but it can happen at any time while taking it.
Like all NSAIDs, it can raise your risk of having blood clots, heart attack, or stroke.
Can lower kidney function or cause permanent kidney damage. These problems are more likely the longer you take it.

risks_warnings.title: Heart attack or stroke
risks_warnings.description: Diclofenac sodium can increase your chance of having blood clots, heart attack, or stroke. Take the lowest dose for the shortest time possible to lower your risk. Never take Diclofenac sodium during the first two weeks after having heart surgery.

risks_warnings.title: Stomach bleeding
risks_warnings.description: Diclofenac sodium can cause serious stomach problems that include inflammation, ulcers, bleeding, and holes in the stomach or intestines. The chances that a stomach problem will occur is worse the longer you take this medication, but it can happen at any time.
risk_factors: History of stomach bleeding or ulcers

description_processed.orig: Diclofenac sodium can cause serious stomach problems that include inflammation, ulcers, bleeding, and holes in the stomach or intestines. The chances that a stomach problem will occur is worse the longer you take this medication, but it can happen at any time.

risks_warnings.title: Bruising or bleeding
risks_warnings.description: You can bruise more easily while using Diclofenac sodium. If you're bleeding, it can take longer than normal for the bleeding to stop. Tell your doctor about all of your medical conditions and medications before starting Diclofenac sodium. Don't take Diclofenac sodium while using other blood thinning medications unless your doctor tells you it is safe.

risks_warnings.title: Serious allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: Rarely, Diclofenac sodium can cause serious allergic reactions. These reactions can make it difficult to breath or cause a severe rash that can be life-threatening. Stop taking Diclofenac sodium and report any skin rash, fever, swelling, or trouble breathing to a doctor or get medical help right away.

risks_warnings.title: Lowers kidney function
risks_warnings.description: Diclofenac sodium, and similar medications in the NSAID family, can lower kidney function or cause permanent kidney damage. Taking the lowest dose for the shortest amount of time necessary can lower your risk of kidney problems. It's important to get lab tests to check your kidney function periodically if you use Diclofenac sodium for long periods of time.
risk_factors: Taking ACE inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs)

risks_warnings.title: Increased blood pressure
risks_warnings.description: Diclofenac sodium can raise your blood pressure.  Most people usually don't feel any differently when their blood pressure is high, so check your blood pressure periodically to watch out for it. If you have high blood pressure and need a medication for the long-term treatment of pain, talk with your doctor since a different medication may be better for you.

basics.benefits_moa: Indomethacin is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). It blocks the inflammation process in your body, which relieves swelling and pain.
basics.bottom_line: Indomethacin works well for mild to moderate pain and swelling, but it shouldn't be used long-term since it has some serious side effects.
downsides: Indomethacin can cause serious heart and stomach problems. The risk goes up the longer you take it, but problems can happen at any time. Don't take Indomethacin any longer than your doctor recommends.
Indomethacin raises your risk of bleeding, especially when taken with other blood-thinning medicines.
There are similar medicines that you don't have to take as often and can work just as well.
Not a good choice if you have kidney, liver, or stomach problems.

risks_warnings.title: Heart attack or stroke
risks_warnings.description: Cambia can increase your chance of having blood clots, heart attack, or stroke. Take the lowest dose for the shortest time possible to lower your risk. Never take Cambia during the first two weeks after having heart surgery.

description_processed.orig: Cambia can increase your chance of having blood clots, heart attack, or stroke. Take the lowest dose for the shortest time possible to lower your risk. Never take Cambia during the first two weeks after having heart surgery.

risks_warnings.title: Stomach bleeding

risk_factors: History of stomach bleeding or ulcers

description_processed.orig: Cambia can cause serious stomach problems that include inflammation, ulcers, bleeding, and holes in the stomach or intestines. The chances that a stomach problem will occur is worse the longer you take this medication, but it can happen at any time.

risks_warnings.title: Bruising or bleeding
risks_warnings.description: You can bruise more easily while using Cambia. If you're bleeding, it can take longer than normal for the bleeding to stop. Tell your doctor about all of your medical conditions and medications before starting Cambia. Don't take Cambia while using other blood thinning medications unless your doctor tells you it is safe.

risks_warnings.title: Lowers kidney function
risks_warnings.description: Cambia, and similar medications in the NSAID family, can lower kidney function or cause permanent kidney damage. Taking the lowest dose for the shortest amount of time necessary can lower your risk of kidney problems. It's important to get lab tests to check your kidney function periodically if you use Cambia for long periods of time.

risks_warnings.title: Increased blood pressure
risks_warnings.description: Cambia can raise your blood pressure.  Most people usually don't feel any differently when their blood pressure is high, so check your blood pressure periodically to watch out for it. If you have high blood pressure and need a medication for the long-term treatment of pain, talk with your doctor since a different medication may be better for you.

risks_warnings.title: Reaction to aspartame (phenylalanine)
risks_warnings.description: Cambia packets contain aspartame (phenylalanine). People who have phenylketonuria (PKU) can't break down the amino acid phenylalanine. It builds up and causes serious medical problems. If you have PKU don't take Cambia packets. There are other dosage forms that may be better for you. Ask your doctor or pharmacist.

risks_warnings.title: Low blood pressure
risks_warnings.description: Codeine commonly cause a sudden drop in blood pressure, especially when you change positions, such as going from sitting to standing. This is called orthostatic hypotension. If you're sensitive to low blood pressure, change position slowly until your body is used to the medicine. Be careful since you can feel dizzy or fall. If symptoms continues for more than a week, you may need to change the dose or medicine.

risks_warnings.title: Serotonin syndrome
risks_warnings.description: Serotonin syndrome is a rare but potentially life-threatening condition caused when there's too much serotonin active in the brain. Your risk goes up if you use Codeine with other medications that affect serotonin (other antidepressants, lithium, triptans, St. John's wort). Symptoms include fast heart rate, sweating, muscle stiffness or spasms, fever, and confusion. Get medical attention right away if you have symptoms.

risks_warnings.title: Tolerance and dependence
risks_warnings.description: If you use Codeine for 4 weeks or more, it's likely that your body will develop tolerance to it, which means that more and more of the medication is needed to achieve the same effect. You're also likely to become physically dependent on the medication, which means that you'll feel withdrawal symptoms if you stop taking it all at once. You can avoid withdrawal by weaning off of the medication very slowly with the help of a doctor. Take only the prescribed dose to minimize risks of abuse and overdose. Codeine should not be used by people with a history of drug abuse if an alternative medication is available.

It's very important to keep Dilaudid away from children, since it can stop them from breathing.

risks_warnings.title: Death from lack of oxygen to the body (respiratory depression)
risks_warnings.description: Taking too much Dilaudid can cause irregular or slow breathing that can put you in a coma and can cause death. If your lips and fingers start turning blue from low oxygen, see a doctor immediately. In the hospital, doctors can give you a medicine that reverses the effects of Dilaudid. Don't take more than your doctor prescribes. Always check with your doctor before starting any new medicines or supplements.
risk_factors: Current use of medicine that affects liver enzyme CYP 3A4
People with not enough thyroid hormones

description_processed.orig: Taking too much Dilaudid can cause irregular or slow breathing that can put you in a coma and can cause death. If your lips and fingers start turning blue from low oxygen, see a doctor immediately. In the hospital, doctors can give you a medicine that reverses the effects of Dilaudid. Don't take more than your doctor prescribes. Always check with your doctor before starting any new medicines or supplements.

risks_warnings.title: Death from overdose
risks_warnings.description: Even one dose of Dilaudid can be too much for children. Keep the medicine out of reach from children. If you suspect your child has taken Dilaudid, watch for decreased activity, extreme tiredness, and lips and fingers turning blue from low oxygen. Go to a hospital immediately and the doctors can give a medicine that reverses the effects of Dilaudid.

risks_warnings.description: Let your doctor know if you have used Dilaudid during pregnancy. Your baby may need special care after birth from experts in this area.

risks_warnings.title: Tolerance, dependence, and addiction
risks_warnings.description: Extended-release and long-acting opioid pain relievers like Dilaudid have a greater risk of addiction, abuse, misuse, overdose, and death. Your body can develop tolerance to Dilaudid, which means that more medicine is needed to treat the same pain. You may become physically dependent on Dilaudid if you have been using it continuously for 2 to 3 weeks or longer, which means that you'll feel withdrawal symptoms if you stop taking it. You can avoid withdrawal by weaning off of the medication very slowly with the help of a doctor. Take only the prescribed dose. People with a history of drug abuse shouldn't take Dilaudid if an alternative medicine is available.

Careful reduction from your maintenance dose is important. It shouldn't be more than 10% of the total daily dose, reduced every 10 to 14 days.

basics.benefits_moa: Methadone is an opioid medicine (similar to morphine) that works in the brain to lower pain perception. Because withdrawal from Methadone is slower, takes longer, and is less severe than other opioids, it's used under the care of a doctor to treat opioid addiction.
basics.bottom_line: Methadone works well for moderate to severe pain especially nerve-related and complex pain and is effective for maintenance opioid addiction treatment. You need to be careful with dosing.
downsides: Need to use it “around-the-clock for pain control not “as needed”.
Even one dose is too much for child or pet and is a medical emergency so store out of their reach.
Can cause slowed breathing, coma and death from overdose, especially if you mix with other nervous system depressants.
Has a higher risk of affecting heart rate control especially if you have cardiovascular disease (previous heart attack, stroke, fast/uncontrolled heart rate, or irregular heart beat).
Can reduce your ability to focus, think, and react so avoid activities that require you to be alert, such as driving a car or operating machinery, until you know how this medicine affects you.
Not safe to take if you're pregnant or breast-feeding and can increase the risk of neonatal withdrawal syndrome in women with a history of long-term opioid use.

May cause you to become tolerant (more medicine is needed to treat the same pain) and physically dependent if you’ve used it for a while so don’t stop talking it suddenly or you may feel withdrawal symptoms.
Can cause your blood pressure drop suddenly if you change positions quickly.
Certain prescription and over-the-counter medicines can change the amount of medicine in your body and cause either overdose or withdrawal.

drugs.name: Methadone

carousel_items_processed.orig: Long-acting opioid for moderate to severe pain.
May not be the best choice for people who have never taken opioids, or who've only taken shorter-acting opioids for pain.
May be part of a complete program to reduce opioid dependence.
For short-term treatment of opioid dependence, the target dose is 40mg for 2-3 days, then reduced every 2 days.
For long-term drug detoxification treatment the dose is increased until withdrawal symptoms stay away for 24 hours.
Dosing can vary widely, but for most people the general range is 80-120mg daily.
Take exactly as your doctor instructs and don’t take more than you're prescribed.
Can make you dizzy or drowsy.
Avoid activities that need you to be fully alert until you know how it affects you.
Don't mix with alcohol or other sedating drugs.
Constipation is common and may not go away while you're taking this medicine. Drinking lots of water and taking laxatives can help.
Talk to your doctor if it doesn't help enough for your pain.
If you need to stop taking this medicine, work with your doctor to slowly lower your dose. It'll help you avoid withdrawal symptoms.
Careful reduction from your maintenance dose is important. It shouldn't be more than 10% of the total daily dose, reduced every 10 to 14 days.

risks_warnings.title: Death from lack of oxygen to the body (respiratory depression)
risks_warnings.description: Taking too much Methadone can cause irregular or slow breathing that can put you in a coma and can cause death. Serious breathing effects can happen after pain relief but may last longer. If your lips and fingers start turning blue from low oxygen, see a doctor immediately. In the hospital, doctors can give you a medicine that reverses the effects of Methadone. Don't take more than your doctor prescribes.
risk_factors: People with not enough thyroid hormones

In the hospital, doctors can give you a medicine that reverses the effects of Methadone. Don't take more than your doctor prescribes.

risks_warnings.title: Heart problems (arrhythmias)
risks_warnings.description: Methadone has a higher risk of affecting heart rate control. If you have a history of cardiovascular disease (including previous heart attack, stroke, fast/uncontrolled heart rate, or irregular heartbeat), talk to your doctor before use. Seek medical attention immediately if you feel faint and have palpitations.

risks_warnings.title: Driving impairment
risks_warnings.description: Methadone lowers your ability to focus, think, and react. Be careful. Avoid activities that require you to be alert, such as driving a car or operating machinery, until you know how this medicine affects you.
risk_factors: Taking other medicines that make you less alert

risks_warnings.title: Drug interactions
risks_warnings.description: Some medicines can affect enzymes that break down Methadone. Certain drugs to treat infections, HIV, and seizures can change the amount of Methadone in the body and cause either overdose or withdrawal. Tell your doctor about any prescription or over-the-counter medications you are taking.
risk_factors: Taking drugs that slow or stop breakdown the breakdown of Methadone

risks_warnings.title: Low blood pressure
risks_warnings.description: Methadone can cause severe low blood pressure, fainting, and a drop blood pressure when you change positions, called orthostatic hypotension. You may be more sensitive if you're already taking medicine to lower your blood pressure so be careful. It's important that you tell your doctor about these symptoms before changing your dose or stopping your medication suddenly.
risk_factors: Taking drugs that lower blood pressure

risks_warnings.title: Neonatal withdrawal syndrome
risks_warnings.description: Methadone passes into breast milk. Women with a history of long-term opioid use increase the risk of neonatal withdrawal syndrome. Symptoms include irritability, vomiting, diarrhea, tremor and lack of weight gain. Opioid withdrawal in infants is a life-threatening emergency and needs medical help right away.
risk_factors: Long-term use of opioids in mother

description_processed.orig: Methadone passes into breast milk. Women with a history of long-term opioid use increase the risk of neonatal withdrawal syndrome. Symptoms include irritability, vomiting, diarrhea, tremor and lack of weight gain. Opioid withdrawal in infants is a life-threatening emergency and needs medical help right away.

risks_warnings.title: Death from overdose
risks_warnings.description: Even 1 dose of Methadone can be too much for a child so store out of reach from children. In adults, raising the dose too quickly, high doses or mixing with alcohol or drugs that interact causes overdose and death. If you suspect a child has taken Methadone, or an adult has taken too much, watch them for decreased activity, extreme tiredness small pupils, and lips and fingers turning blue from low oxygen. Call 911 or go to a hospital immediately. Doctors can give a medicine that reverses the effects of Methadone until the effects wear off.
risk_factors: Mixing with alcohol or drugs that interact with Methadone

risks_warnings.title: Abuse, tolerance, and addiction
risks_warnings.description: Long-acting opioids like Methadone have a greater risk of addiction, abuse, misuse, overdose, and death. Your body can develop tolerance to Methadone, which means that more medicine is needed to treat the same pain. You can become physically dependent on Methadone if you have been using it continuously for more than 1-2 weeks, meaning you'll feel withdrawal symptoms if you stop taking it. You can avoid withdrawal by weaning off of the medication very slowly and taking the exact dose your doctor prescribed. People taking Methadone for pain with a history of drug abuse should ask their doctor about other medicine choices.
risk_factors: Taking more than the prescribed dose
History of drug abuse or mental illness.

It's a dangerous medication for pregnant women.

Never take Oxycodone/Ibuprofen during the first two weeks after having heart surgery.

risks_warnings.title: Stomach bleeding
risks_warnings.description: Oxycodone/Ibuprofen can cause serious stomach problems that include inflammation, ulcers, bleeding, and holes in the stomach or intestines. The chances that a stomach problem will occur might be worse the longer you take this medication, but it can happen at any time. Watch out for blood or dark colored stools when you go to the bathroom. This can be a medical emergency and you should get help right away.

risks_warnings.title: Bruising or bleeding
risks_warnings.description: You can bruise more easily while using Oxycodone/Ibuprofen. If you're bleeding, it can take longer than normal for the bleeding to stop. Tell your doctor about all of the medication(s) that you take and all of your medical conditions before starting Oxycodone/Ibuprofen. Don't take Oxycodone/Ibuprofen while using other blood thinning medications unless your doctor tells you it is safe.

risks_warnings.title: Lowers kidney function
risks_warnings.description: Oxycodone/Ibuprofen, and similar medications in the NSAID family, can lower kidney function or cause permanent kidney damage. Taking the lowest dose for the shortest amount of time necessary can lower your risk for kidney problems. It's important to get lab tests to check your kidney function periodically if you use Oxycodone/Ibuprofen for long periods of time.

risks_warnings.title: Death from lack of oxygen to the body (respiratory depression)
risks_warnings.description: Taking too much Oxycodone can cause irregular or slow breathing that can put you in a coma and can cause death. Oxycodone should be swallowed whole, don't ever crush or chew. If your lips and fingers start turning blue from low oxygen, see a doctor immediately. Always check with your doctor before starting any new medicines or supplements.

risks_warnings.title: Death from overdose

Go to a hospital immediately and the doctors can give a medicine that reverses the effects of Oxycodone until the effects wear off.

risks_warnings.title: Tolerance, dependence, and addiction
risks_warnings.description: Extended-release and long-acting opioid pain relievers like Oxycodone have a greater risk of addiction, abuse, misuse, overdose, and death. You body can develop tolerance to Oxycodone, which means that more medicine is needed to treat the same pain. You may become physically dependent on Oxycodone if you have been using it continuously for 2-3 weeks or longer, which means that you'll feel withdrawal symptoms if you stop taking it. You can avoid withdrawal by weaning off of the medication very slowly with the help of a doctor. Take only the prescribed dose. People with a history of drug abuse shouldn't take Oxycodone if an alternative medicine is available.
risk_factors: Taking more than the prescribed dose

If symptoms continues for more than a few doses, another pain medicine may be better for you.

risks_warnings.title: Severe allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: Oxycodone can cause hypersensitivity reactions (severe rash, trouble breathing) and angioedema (life-threatening condition with swelling with or without hives). This is a medical emergency and you get medical attention immediately. You shouldn’t take Oxycodone if you've had an allergic reaction to certain opioids like codeine, hydromorphone, hydrocodone, levorphanol, and oxymorphone. Talk to your doctor about other pain medicine choices.

basics.benefits_moa: Indomethacin is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). It blocks the inflammation process in your body, which relieves swelling and pain.
basics.bottom_line: Indomethacin works well for mild to moderate pain and swelling, but it shouldn't be used long-term since it has some serious side effects.
downsides: Indomethacin can cause serious heart and stomach problems. The risk goes up the longer you take it, but problems can happen at any time. Don't take Indomethacin any longer than your doctor recommends.
Indomethacin raises your risk of bleeding, especially when taken with other blood-thinning medicines.
There are similar medicines that you don't have to take as often and can work just as well.
Not a good choice if you have kidney, liver, or stomach problems.

risks_warnings.title: Heart attack or stroke
risks_warnings.description: Indomethacin can increase your chance of having blood clots, heart attack, or stroke. The risk can increase the longer you take it. Talk to your doctor about taking the lowest dose that works for you for the shortest time possible.

description_processed.orig: Indomethacin can increase your chance of having blood clots, heart attack, or stroke. The risk can increase the longer you take it. Talk to your doctor about taking the lowest dose that works for you for the shortest time possible.

risks_warnings.title: Stomach bleeding
risks_warnings.description: Indomethacin can cause serious stomach problems, such as ulcers, bleeding, and holes in the stomach or intestines. These problems can be life-threatening and can cause death. The risk can increase the longer you take it, but it can happen at any time. Watch out for blood or dark-colored stools. This can be a medical emergency and you should get help right away.
risk_factors: History of stomach bleeding or ulcers

risks_warnings.title: Harm to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Indomethacin may cause birth defects. Don't use Indomethacin while pregnant. If you're considering having a baby, talk to your doctor about alternative medications.

description_processed.orig: Indomethacin may cause birth defects. Don't use Indomethacin while pregnant. If you're considering having a baby, talk to your doctor about alternative medications.

risks_warnings.title: Serious allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: Rarely, Indomethacin can cause serious allergic reactions.  These reactions can make it difficult to breath or cause a severe rash that can be life threatening. If you have Asthma, don't take Indomethacin if you're experiencing a runny nose (Rhinitis) with or without nasal polyps.  Also, don't take Indomethacin if you've experienced an asthma attack after taking aspirin or other NSAID type medications.  Stop taking Indomethacin and report any skin rash, fever, swelling, or trouble breathing to a doctor right away.

carousel_items: Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen is a medicine that's used for short-term moderate to severe pain, usually no more than 10 days. Talk to your doctor if your pain lasts longer than 10 days.
Takes about 10 to 20 minutes to start working and can last about 4 to 8 hours.
Can cause headache, constipation, nausea, drowsiness, and dizziness.
Don't drink alcohol with Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen.
Can cause stomach ulcers or bleeding. Don't take it with other blood-thinning medicines without talking to your doctor first.
Take with food or milk to help prevent upset stomach.

basics.benefits_moa: Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen is a combination medicine with two pain relievers. One is an opioid that blocks pain receptors in the brain; the other is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that prevents inflammation.
basics.bottom_line: Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen works well for moderate to severe pain, but it shouldn't be used long-term.
downsides: Not used for long-term pain or for conditions like osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis.
Can cause serious heart and stomach problems. The risk goes up the longer you take it, but problems can happen at any time. Don't take Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen any longer than your doctor recommends.
Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen raises your risk of bleeding, especially when taken with other blood-thinning medicines.
You can experience withdrawal symptoms if you suddenly stop taking Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen.
Not a good choice if you have high blood pressure or kidney, liver, or stomach problems.

risks_warnings.title: Heart attack or stroke
risks_warnings.description: Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen can increase your chance of having blood clots, heart attack, or stroke. The risk can increase the longer you take it. Talk to your doctor about taking the lowest dose that works for you for the shortest time possible.

description_processed.orig: Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen can increase your chance of having blood clots, heart attack, or stroke. The risk can increase the longer you take it. Talk to your doctor about taking the lowest dose that works for you for the shortest time possible.

risks_warnings.title: Stomach bleeding
risks_warnings.description: Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen can cause serious stomach problems, such as ulcers, bleeding, and holes in the stomach or intestines. These problems can be life-threatening and can cause death. The risk can increase the longer you take it, but it can happen at any time. Watch out for blood or dark-colored stools. This can be a medical emergency and you should get help right away.
risk_factors: History of stomach bleeding or ulcers

risks_warnings.title: Driving impairment
risks_warnings.description: Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen lowers your ability to focus, think, and react. Be careful. Avoid activities that require you to be alert, such as driving a car or operating machinery, until you know how this medication affects you.
risk_factors: Taking other medicines that make you less alert

risks_warnings.title: Harm to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen may cause birth defects. Don't use Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen while pregnant. If you're considering having a baby, talk to your doctor about alternative medications.

description_processed.orig: Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen may cause birth defects. Don't use Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen while pregnant. If you're considering having a baby, talk to your doctor about alternative medications.

risks_warnings.title: Low blood pressure
risks_warnings.description: Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen commonly cause a sudden drop in blood pressure, especially when you change positions, such as going from sitting to standing. This is called orthostatic hypotension. If you're sensitive to low blood pressure, change position slowly until your body is used to the medicine. Be careful since you can feel dizzy or fall. If symptoms continues for more than a week, you may need to change the dose or medicine.

carousel_items: This is a combination pain medication. It contains both an opioid medicine and acetaminophen (Tylenol).
Works best if you take it as soon as you start feeling pain. Starts working in 30 minutes and pain relief lasts 4 to 6 hours.
Can make you dizzy or drowsy. Avoid activities need you to be fully alert until you know how it affects you.
Take it with food to lower the chance of an upset stomach.
Constipation is common and may not go away while you're taking this medicine. Drinking lots of water and using laxatives can help.
Don't take more than instructed to prevent liver damage.
Use it for the shortest time and at the lowest dose possible, to lower your chance of becoming addicted.
Talk to your doctor if it doesn't work well enough to relieve your pain, or if the side effects are really bad.

basics.benefits_moa: Norco is a combination pain medicine. Hydrocodone is an opioid (similar to morphine) that works in the brain to lower pain perception. Acetaminophen is a non-opioid pain reliever and fever reducer.
basics.bottom_line: Norco is a good option to treat pain as needed when over-the-counter medicines can't control the symptoms, but must make sure you don't take too much acetaminophen (Tylenol) to avoid liver problems or death.
downsides: Dizziness and drowsiness is common.
Everyone will get constipation - always stay hydrated and take stool softener or stimulant on days you're taking Norco if you need.
All opioid containing medicines have the risk of physical dependence and possibility of withdrawal when used long-term.
The non-opioid part of Norco, acetaminophen (Tylenol), has a high risk of liver failure and death if you take more than the maximum daily dose. Be very careful.
Relies on the users to be aware of how much acetaminophen (Tylenol) they are using since it is a very common ingredient in many prescription and non-prescription pain medicines.
Avoid alcohol.

upsides: Combination pain medicine with an opiod component (hydrocodone) and non-opioid component (acetaminophen or Tylenol) that takes advantage of different modes of pain relieve in a single pill.
Provides quick relief for moderate to severe pain to improve quality of life.
Good for as-needed, short-term use, but may be helpful to manage more long-term pain problems if used at the appropriate doses and intervals.
Generally well tolerated by people, especially if taken with food to lower risk of stomach upset.
Lower rates of misuse compared to pure opioid medicines.
Can help you fall asleep easier.

risks_warnings.title: Death from liver failure
risks_warnings.description: The acetaminophen component in Norco can hurt your liver. Using more than 4000 mg of the acetaminophen (or 12 tablets of Norco can cause serious harm to your liver. You may develop life-threatening liver problems that need a liver transplant. Don't take more than your doctor prescribes, and avoid other medicines that have acetaminophen when using Norco.

description_processed.orig: The acetaminophen component in Norco can hurt your liver. Using more than 4000 mg of the acetaminophen (or 12 tablets of Norco can cause serious harm to your liver. risks_warnings.title: Death from lack of oxygen to the body (respiratory depression)
risks_warnings.description: Taking too much Norco can cause irregular or slow breathing that can put you in a coma and can cause death. If your lips and fingers start turning blue from low oxygen, see a doctor immediately. In the hospital, doctors can give you a medicine that reverses the effects of Norco. Don't take more than your doctor prescribes.

risks_warnings.title: Severe allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: Norco can cause hypersensitivity reactions (severe rash, trouble breathing) and angioedema (life-threatening condition with swelling with or without hives). This is a medical emergency and you get medical attention immediately. You shouldn’t take Norco if you've had an allergic reaction to certain opioids like codeine, hydromorphone, levorphanol, oxycodone, and oxymorphone. Talk to your doctor about other pain medicine choices.

risks_warnings.title: Neonatal withdrawal syndrome
risks_warnings.description: Hydrocodone, one of the medications in Norco passes into breast milk. Women with a history of long-term opioid use increase the risk of neonatal withdrawal syndrome. Symptoms in the newborn include irritability, vomiting, diarrhea, tremor and lack of weight gain. Opioid withdrawal in infants is a life-threatening emergency and needs medical help right away.
risk_factors: Long-term use of opioids in mother

risks_warnings.title: Tolerance and dependence
risks_warnings.description: You body can develop tolerance to Norco, which means that more medicine is needed to treat the same pain. You may become physically dependent on Norco if you have been using it continuously for 2-3 weeks or longer, which means that you'll feel withdrawal symptoms if you stop taking it. You can avoid withdrawal by weaning off of the medication very slowly with the help of a doctor. Take only the prescribed dose for the shortest duration to lower risks of abuse and overdose. People with a history of drug abuse shouldn't take Norco if an alternative medicine is available.
risk_factors: Taking more than the prescribed dose

risks_warnings.title: Death from overdose (extended-release tablet)
risks_warnings.description: Even 1 dose of an extended-release tablet can be too much for a child so store out of reach from children. In adults, raising the dose too quickly, high doses or mixing with alcohol or drugs that interact causes overdose and death. If you suspect a child has taken Percocet, or an adult has taken too much, watch them for decreased activity, extreme tiredness small pupils, and lips and fingers turning blue from low oxygen. Call 911 or go to a hospital immediately. Doctors can give a medicine that reverses the effects of Percocet.

You shouldn’t take Percocet if you've had an allergic reaction to certain opioids like codeine, hydromorphone, hydrocodone, levorphanol, and oxymorphone. Talk to your doctor about other pain medicine choices.

risks_warnings.title: Low blood pressure
risks_warnings.description: The oxycodone part of Percocet can lower your blood pressure. You may feel dizzy, lightheaded. If you're sensitive to low blood pressure, change position slowly, such as going from sitting to standing since that is when you will feel the low blood pressure the most. If symptoms continues for more than a few doses, another pain medicine may be better for you.

carousel_items: Starts working in one hour and works best if you take it regularly.
Can make you dizzy or drowsy, so avoid activities that need you to be fully alert until you know how this medicine affects you.
Take Tramadol with food to avoid an upset stomach.
There are different doses for people who are older or who have liver or kidney disease, so work with your doctor to get the right dose.
Swallow the extended-release tablets whole. They're designed to release the drug slowly and breaking, crushing, or chewing them could cause a serious overdose.

basics.benefits_moa: Tramadol is an atypical opioid pain reliever. Researchers don't know exactly how it works, but it alters certain brain chemicals to lower pain perception and improve mood.
basics.bottom_line: Tramadol works well to treat severe pain and mood changes. Although it's a little weaker than other opioids, it can still be addictive.
downsides: Some people think it's weaker than other opioid pain medications. It can also cause more upset stomach.

Like other opioid pain relievers, Tramadol has a high risk of addiction, abuse, misuse, overdose, and death. It should only be used for severe pain that requires daily, around-the-clock treatment once alternative treatments haven't worked.
It isn't used for short-term, as-needed pain relief.
It's a controlled substance regulated by the federal government. This means that your use of Tramadol will be tracked to prevent potential prescription abuse.
To get Tramadol in the pharmacy, you'll need to bring in a paper prescription directly from your doctor.

upsides: Relieves moderate to severe pain. It has been shown to work as well as other opioid pain medications.
Compared to typical opioids, it provides unique pain relief and effects on your mood when taken regularly.
Has a lower chance of causing breathing problems compared to other typical opioids.
Doesn't cause as much constipation as other opioid pain medicines. Staying hydrated and taking laxatives can help treat this side effect.

drugs.name: Tramadol

carousel_items_processed.orig: Starts working in one hour and works best if you take it regularly.
Can make you dizzy or drowsy, so avoid activities that need you to be fully alert until you know how this medicine affects you.
Take Tramadol with food to avoid an upset stomach.
There are different doses for people who are older or who have liver or kidney disease, so work with your doctor to get the right dose.
Swallow the extended-release tablets whole. They're designed to release the drug slowly and breaking, crushing, or chewing them could cause a serious overdose.

risks_warnings.title: Seizures
risks_warnings.description: Tramadol can lower the brain's threshold for seizures in people with certain risk factors. Use with caution.
risk_factors: Using other medicines that can cause seizures

description_processed.orig: Tramadol can lower the brain's threshold for seizures in people with certain risk factors. Use with caution.

risks_warnings.title: Suicidal thoughts or behavior
risks_warnings.description: People who are suicidal, at risk for suicide, or prone to addiction should not take Tramadol. People who are depressed or taking antidepressants should be monitored closely by a doctor. Watch for worsening depression, suicidal thoughts or behavior, or any unusual changes in mood or behavior. Report anything concerning to a doctor immediately.
risk_factors: Taking other medications that affect serotonin

description_processed.orig: People who are suicidal, at risk for suicide, or prone to addiction should not take Tramadol. People who are depressed or taking antidepressants should be monitored closely by a doctor. Watch for worsening depression, suicidal thoughts or behavior, or any unusual changes in mood or behavior. Report anything concerning to a doctor immediately.

risks_warnings.title: Serotonin syndrome
risks_warnings.description: Serotonin syndrome is a rare but potentially life-threatening condition caused when there's too much serotonin active in the brain. Your risk goes up if you use Tramadol with other medications that affect serotonin (other antidepressants, lithium, triptans, St. John's wort). Symptoms include fast heart rate, sweating, muscle stiffness or spasms, fever, and confusion. Go to the hopspital right away if you have symptoms.
risk_factors: Using other medications that affect serotonin

description_processed.orig: Serotonin syndrome is a rare but potentially life-threatening condition caused when there's too much serotonin active in the brain. Your risk goes up if you use Tramadol with other medications that affect serotonin (other antidepressants, lithium, triptans, St. John's wort). Symptoms include fast heart rate, sweating, muscle stiffness or spasms, fever, and confusion. Go to the hopspital right away if you have symptoms.

risks_warnings.title: Serious allergic (anaphylactoid) reactions
risks_warnings.description: Rare, sudden allergic reactions (including death) can occur, usually after the first dose. Symptoms include difficulty breathing; swelling of the face, tongue, and throat; and itching or hives. This is a medical emergency. People with sensitivity to phenylketones and phenylalanine should NOT take the orally disintegrating tablet (Rybix ODT). This formulation contains phenylalanine in an inactive ingredient.
risk_factors: History of allergic reactions to codeine or other opioid pain relievers

description_processed.orig: Rare, sudden allergic reactions (including death) can occur, usually after the first dose. Symptoms include difficulty breathing; swelling of the face, tongue, and throat; and itching or hives. This is a medical emergency. People with sensitivity to phenylketones and phenylalanine should NOT take the orally disintegrating tablet (Rybix ODT). This formulation contains phenylalanine in an inactive ingredient.

risks_warnings.title: Withdrawal
risks_warnings.description: Suddenly stopping Tramadol after long periods of use or after high doses can produce withdrawal symptoms, including anxiety, sweating, insomnia, pain, nausea, shaking chills, tremors, diarrhea, nose and throat irritation, raised body hair (piloerection), and hallucinations. Discontinue slowly with the help of a doctor.

description_processed.orig: Suddenly stopping Tramadol after long periods of use or after high doses can produce withdrawal symptoms, including anxiety, sweating, insomnia, pain, nausea, shaking chills, tremors, diarrhea, nose and throat irritation, raised body hair (piloerection), and hallucinations. Discontinue slowly with the help of a doctor.

risks_warnings.title: Serious side effects and overdose
risks_warnings.description: Serious side effects may include drug abuse, dependence, slowed breathing rate (respiratory depression), and death. Don't take more than your doctor prescribes or take with alcohol, illegal drugs, or other opioid pain relievers.
risk_factors: Taking more than the prescribed dose

description_processed.orig: Serious side effects may include drug abuse, dependence, slowed breathing rate (respiratory depression), and death. Don't take more than your doctor prescribes or take with alcohol, illegal drugs, or other opioid pain relievers.

risks_warnings.title: Driving impairment
risks_warnings.description: Tramadol lowers your ability to focus, think, and react. Be careful. Avoid activities that require you to be alert, such as driving a car or operating machinery, until you know how this medication affects you.

description_processed.orig: Tramadol lowers your ability to focus, think, and react. Be careful. Avoid activities that require you to be alert, such as driving a car or operating machinery, until you know how this medication affects you.

risks_warnings.title: Extended-release form
risks_warnings.description: (1) Extended-release and long-acting opioid pain relievers have a greater risk of addiction, abuse, misuse, overdose, and death. Therefore, they should only be used for severe pain that requires daily, around-the-clock treatment, and only if alternative treatments aren't working. They should not be used for as-needed pain relief. (2) Swallow extended-release tablets whole. They're designed to release the drug slowly, so breaking, crushing, or chewing them could cause a lethal overdose.
